content.description: Start at the two low pockets to the left of the right arete.  Move up using the arete edge, pockets, and side pulls.
content.location: This route is on the side of the boulder that is almost facing towards (but not quite parallel to) "Rappel Rock" (the sport climbing/toproping wall face).

content.description: Climbs the right arete of the north face. Stand start on the left of the arete with right hand on a wide pinch of the arete and left hand in a deep slopey pocket. Slap up the arete to a better pinch and climb up the left side of the arete through a good pocket.
content.location: Right arete of the north face of Ross Boulder. Stand start at #4 in the topo photo.Getting down from the top is an easy walk down to lower ground.

content.description: Sit start on the face closer to Sunshine Wall (east face?) near the arete, climb up through large holds staying left of the arete to a sloping top out.
content.location: On the east face near the arete (left of the left arete of the north face).

content.description: Start to the right of the left arete on Ross' Boulder.  Climb straight up using obvious flake and finish at just right of the arete.

Unknown boulder near the north end of the Rim Road area. 

  This was a cool boulder for beginner/intermediate, V1-ish.  

  I did not find this boulder listed, so here is a pic just to help others. I'm not a PA local and it was clearly climbed a lot as there was chalk on a lot of it, sorry I don't know the name. There were several fun easier routes here and one harder one. If someone has names for the boulder or routes, please update it. I'd say it's generally V1, except 'the hard route' #4 starting right hand on the right edge of the west side.  

  The crux for the north face (what I marked 1,2,3) is near the top simply because the holds are a little smaller. The west face sit starts were kind of hard too for us as novices, but standing starts were easy to get going and fun still.
